title: Ezekiel Chapter 25 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 25 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 25 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 25.

questions.question: Who is Ezekiel instructed to set his face against and prophesy against in Ezekiel 25?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ammonites
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:2 instructs the son of man to set his face against the Ammonites and prophesy against them.

questions.question: Why does God say He will deliver the Ammonites to the men of the east?
options: Because they rejoiced over Israel's desolation
questions.correctAnswer: Because they rejoiced over Israel's desolation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:3-4 explains God will deliver the Ammonites because they said 'Aha' against His sanctuary when it was profaned and rejoiced over Israel's captivity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 25:5, what will Rabbah become?
questions.correctAnswer: A stable for camels
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:5 states that Rabbah will be made a stable for camels and a couching place for flocks.

questions.question: What action did the Ammonites take that caused God's judgment upon them?
options: Clapped hands and stamped feet in rejoicing against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Clapped hands and stamped feet in rejoicing against Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:6 says the Ammonites clapped their hands and stamped their feet and rejoiced in heart against the land of Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 25 states that the people of Moab said the house of Judah is like all the heathen.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:8 confirms that Moab and Seir said the house of Judah was like all the heathen.

questions.question: Which cities of Moab are mentioned as being opened to the men of the east?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethjeshimoth, Baalmeon, Kiriathaim
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:9 names these cities of Moab as being opened to the men of the east.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I will execute judgments upon Moab; and they shall know that I am the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:11 states that judgments will be executed upon Moab so they will know that the LORD is God.

questions.question: Why does God say He will stretch out His hand upon Edom?
options: Because Edom took vengeance and offended the house of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Because Edom took vengeance and offended the house of Judah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:12-13 states God will punish Edom because they took vengeance and greatly offended Judah.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 25, who will carry out God's vengeance on Edom?
questions.correctAnswer: The people of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:14 indicates that Israel will execute vengeance on Edom as ordained by God.

questions.question: True or False: The Philistines are condemned for taking vengeance with a spiteful heart according to Ezekiel 25.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:15 states the Philistines took vengeance with a despiteful heart and are thus judged.

questions.question: What will God do to the Cherethims according to Ezekiel 25?
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them off
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:16 proclaims that God will cut off the Cherethims as part of judgment on the Philistines.

questions.question: What is the result when God lays His vengeance upon the Philistines?
options: They shall know that I am the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They shall know that I am the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:17 states that God’s vengeance will make the Philistines acknowledge the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 25 describes the Ammonites' punishment as being made into a place for camels and flocks.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:5 says Rabbah will be made a stable for camels and the Ammonites a couching place for flocks.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 25:7, what will happen to the Ammonites?
options: They will be delivered for a spoil to the heathen
They will conquer the land of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They will be delivered for a spoil to the heathen
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:7 clearly states the Ammonites will be delivered for a spoil to the heathen and destroyed.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I will make it desolate from _____; and they of Dedan shall fall by the sword.'
questions.correctAnswer: Teman
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:13 states that Edom will be made desolate from Teman and Dedan will fall by the sword.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 25 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 25 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness after being wronged by others. Based on Ezekiel 25, what biblical truth would you share about God's response to those who rejoice over others' suffering?
options: God delivers judgment on those who rejoice over His people’s suffering.
God ignores those who offend His people.
God rewards those who rejoice over others’ misfortune.
God encourages us to seek revenge ourselves.
questions.correctAnswer: God delivers judgment on those who rejoice over His people’s suffering.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:3-7 explains that God judges the Ammonites because they rejoiced over the desolation of Israel and Judah. This teaches that God opposes those who take pleasure in others' hardship.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 25 teach us about trusting God's justice when facing enemies or opposition?
options: God will personally enact vengeance through His people.
We must take vengeance into our own hands immediately.
God will ignore the offenses against His people.
We should seek to forget offenses without any consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: God will personally enact vengeance through His people.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:14 shows that God will lay His vengeance on Edom by the hand of Israel, indicating that God assures believers that He will execute justice in His timing.

questions.question: In terms of humility and contentment, what can we learn from the judgment on the Philistines who acted with 'old hatred'?
options: Holding onto spite and hatred leads to destruction.
Old hatred is acceptable if justified.
questions.correctAnswer: Holding onto spite and hatred leads to destruction.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:15-17 warns the Philistines for their revengeful actions motivated by old hatred, teaching that bitterness and spite bring judgment and are harmful to spiritual wellbeing.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to respond to insults with anger and spite. Based on Ezekiel 25, how should they view God's role in dealing with those who wrong His people?
options: God will execute vengeance, so believers should remain patient and trust Him.
God ignores offenses and lets them go unpunished.
Believers should harbor anger until justice is served.
questions.correctAnswer: God will execute vengeance, so believers should remain patient and trust Him.
questions.explanation: Verses like Ezekiel 25:11 and 25:17 emphasize God's role in judging those who wrong His people, encouraging believers to trust God’s justice rather than taking vengeance themselves.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 25 instruct believers about the importance of obedience and faithfulness in the face of hostility?
options: Faithfulness leads to God's protection and vindication.
Hostility should cause believers to abandon their faith.
Believers must rely solely on their own strength.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness leads to God's protection and vindication.
questions.explanation: The chapter shows that despite enemies’ actions, God remains sovereign and will vindicate His people (Ezekiel 25:4-7, 25:14), teaching the value of steadfast faith.

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility can we learn from God’s judgment on Edom and Moab in Ezekiel 25?
options: Pride and vengeance against God's people lead to destruction.
questions.correctAnswer: Pride and vengeance against God's people lead to destruction.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:8-13 describes God's judgment on Moab and Edom for their pride and vengeful actions, underscoring the need for humility and trust in God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 25, God promises to restore the Ammonites to their former glory as a reward for their actions against Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:4-5 declares that God will hand the Ammonites over to the men of the east and make their cities desolate, not restore their glory.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 25 teaches that God’s vengeance includes both man and beast when judging Edom.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:13 clearly states that God will cut off man and beast from Edom, indicating complete judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezekiel 25:6-7, God will stretch out His hand upon those who ______ with all their despite against the land of Israel.
options: clapped their hands and stamped with their feet
questions.correctAnswer: clapped their hands and stamped with their feet
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:6-7 describes those who clapped hands and stamped feet in spite against Israel, leading to God's judgment on them.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 25 teach about God's sovereignty in times of trial, especially regarding the enemies of His people?
options: God controls the fate of nations and enacts justice in His timing.
God leaves His people vulnerable without intervention.
Believers must depend on political alliances only.
God supports all nations equally regardless of their actions.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the fate of nations and enacts justice in His timing.
questions.explanation: Throughout Ezekiel 25, God declares He will deliver judgment and control the destiny of nations opposing His people (verses 4, 7, 11, 14, 17).

questions.question: In the context of spiritual discipline and prayer, how can Ezekiel 25 encourage a believer facing opposition?
options: To pray for God’s justice and remain faithful, trusting His timing.
To give up and avoid prayer during trials.
To seek revenge without seeking God.
To ignore God’s promises and rely on human strength.
questions.correctAnswer: To pray for God’s justice and remain faithful, trusting His timing.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25 shows God's active role in judging enemies, encouraging believers to trust God through prayer and faithfulness despite opposition (verses 11, 17).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 25 remind believers about the importance of integrity and honesty in their witness, especially towards hostile neighbors?
options: God judges those who act spitefully and dishonestly against His people.
Deception is acceptable against hostile neighbors.
Integrity is irrelevant when facing opposition.
questions.correctAnswer: God judges those who act spitefully and dishonestly against His people.
questions.explanation: The chapter condemns the spiteful actions of the Philistines and others (Ezekiel 25:15-17), highlighting the call for believers to maintain honesty and integrity.

questions.question: A Christian parent is teaching their children about trusting God amidst adversity. Based on Ezekiel 25, what is a key lesson about God’s character they should emphasize?
options: God is just and will execute vengeance on behalf of His people.
God abandons His people in trouble.
God allows enemies to triumph without consequence.
God is indifferent to the sufferings of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God is just and will execute vengeance on behalf of His people.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25 repeatedly highlights God's justice and vengeance on those who harm His people (verses 7, 11, 14, 17), reassuring believers of His protective care.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 25 instruct believers about forgiveness and love for neighbors in the midst of hostility?
options: While God judges enemies, believers are called to trust Him rather than seek personal revenge.
Believers must hate their enemies as God does.
Believers should repay evil with evil.
questions.correctAnswer: While God judges enemies, believers are called to trust Him rather than seek personal revenge.
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s role in vengeance, encouraging believers to leave judgment to God and respond with faith rather than personal hostility (Ezekiel 25:7,17).

questions.question: What can believers learn from Ezekiel 25 about stewardship and generosity in the face of trials and attacks?
options: Believers should remain faithful stewards, trusting God’s provision despite opposition.
Opposition means God has abandoned provision.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should remain faithful stewards, trusting God’s provision despite opposition.
questions.explanation: Though the chapter focuses on judgment, the underlying call to trust God (Ezekiel 25:4-5) supports faithful stewardship and trust in God’s care during hardship.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 25 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 25.

questions.question: Against which nation did God instruct Ezekiel to prophesy in Ezekiel 25?
questions.correctAnswer: Ammonites
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:2 states that the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel to set his face against the Ammonites and prophesy against them.

questions.question: What was the reason God gave for judging the Ammonites?
options: They rejoiced over the profaning of God's sanctuary
They allied with the Egyptians against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoiced over the profaning of God's sanctuary
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:3-6 explains that the Ammonites said 'Aha' against God's sanctuary when it was profaned and rejoiced against the land of Israel in captivity.

questions.question: What did God say He would make Rabbah to the Ammonites?
questions.correctAnswer: A stable for camels
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:5 states that God will make Rabbah a stable for camels and the Ammonites a couching place for flocks.

questions.question: Which nations are mentioned together as saying that the house of Judah is like all the heathen?
questions.correctAnswer: Moab and Seir
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:8 reports that Moab and Seir say the house of Judah is like all the heathen.

questions.question: Which cities are listed as part of the Moabite territory that will be given to the men of the east?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethjeshimoth, Baalmeon, Kiriathaim
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:9 records these cities as the glory of Moab's country which God will open and give to the men of the east with the Ammonites.

questions.question: What will happen to Edom according to God's judgment in Ezekiel 25?
options: Cut off man and beast and made desolate
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off man and beast and made desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:13 states God will stretch out His hand upon Edom, cut off man and beast, and make it desolate from Teman.

questions.question: Who will carry out God's vengeance on Edom, according to Ezekiel 25?
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:14 notes that God will lay His vengeance upon Edom by the hand of His people Israel.

questions.question: Why were the Philistines judged by God in Ezekiel 25?
options: Because they acted by revenge with a despiteful heart
Because they refused to help Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because they acted by revenge with a despiteful heart
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:15 explains that the Philistines dealt by revenge with a despiteful heart due to old hatred.

questions.question: Who are the Cherethims mentioned in Ezekiel 25:16?
options: A Philistine people who will be cut off
questions.correctAnswer: A Philistine people who will be cut off
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:16 states God will cut off the Cherethims, a Philistine group, and destroy the remnant of the sea coast.

questions.question: What is the repeated phrase used in this chapter that emphasizes God's purpose in these judgments?
options: "that ye shall know that I am the LORD"
questions.correctAnswer: "that ye shall know that I am the LORD"
questions.explanation: Verses 5, 7, 11, and 17 all emphasize that through judgment the nations will know that God is the LORD.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 25, what literary device is prominently used in the pronouncements against the nations?
options: Judicial oracle with divine judgment pronouncement
questions.correctAnswer: Judicial oracle with divine judgment pronouncement
questions.explanation: The chapter presents a series of divine oracles against nations, a common prophetic judicial genre declaring God's judgment.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is reflected in the description of Rabbah becoming a stable for camels?
options: Using conquered cities as pasturage for animals
questions.correctAnswer: Using conquered cities as pasturage for animals
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:5 reflects the humiliation of Rabbah by converting it into a stable for camels, a sign of desolation in ancient Near Eastern culture.

questions.question: True or False: The judgments against Edom include the fall of Dedan by the sword.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:13 clearly states that those of Dedan shall fall by the sword as part of Edom’s desolation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The men of the east are given possession of Moab's cities __________ and __________.
questions.correctAnswer: Bethjeshimoth, Baalmeon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:9 lists these cities among those on Moab's frontiers given to the men of the east.

questions.question: How does the theme of divine vengeance in Ezekiel 25 connect with the broader prophetic literature?
options: It reflects God's justice and retribution toward nations opposing Israel
It celebrates the prosperity of foreign nations
It proclaims universal peace without judgment
It focuses only on Israel's internal reform
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects God's justice and retribution toward nations opposing Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25, like other prophetic books, emphasizes divine vengeance as part of God's righteous judgment on hostile nations.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 25 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 25 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 25, why does God pronounce judgment against the Ammonites?
options: Because they rejoiced against God's sanctuary and the desolation of Israel
Because they built their own temples
questions.correctAnswer: Because they rejoiced against God's sanctuary and the desolation of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:3 states the Ammonites said 'Aha' against God's sanctuary when it was profaned and against Israel's desolation. This reflects their hostile attitude. Similarly, Psalm 79:5 condemns rejoicing over Zion's ruin; Obadiah 1:10 condemns rejoicing over Judah's calamity; and Romans 12:19 affirms God's vengeance on those who wrong His people.

questions.question: What is the specific judgment God declares upon Rabbah, the city of the Ammonites?
options: It will become a stable for camels
It will be burned with fire
It will be flooded by the sea
It will be given to Israel as a city
questions.correctAnswer: It will become a stable for camels
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:5 says God will make Rabbah a stable for camels, symbolizing its desolation and humiliation. This judgment echoes God's use of foreign nations as instruments of judgment in Isaiah 13:21 and Jeremiah 50:39. It illustrates God's sovereign control over nations (Psalm 22:28).

questions.question: What reason does God give for judging Moab and Seir in Ezekiel 25?
options: Because they said the house of Judah is like all the heathen
Because they refused to trade with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because they said the house of Judah is like all the heathen
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:8 records that Moab and Seir disparaged Judah as being like all nations, showing contempt for God's chosen people. This pride and scorn against God's covenant people provoke judgment. Similar themes appear in Jeremiah 48:29 and Amos 2:1-3. God's defense of His people is consistent throughout Scripture (Deuteronomy 32:39).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 25, what is the fate of the cities on Moab's frontiers like Bethjeshimoth and Kiriathaim?
options: They will be given to the men of the east and Ammonites
They will be rebuilt by Israel
They will be spared from destruction
questions.correctAnswer: They will be given to the men of the east and Ammonites
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:9-10 says God will open Moab's cities to the men of the east and the Ammonites, giving them possession. This illustrates God's sovereign judgment by transferring land. The motif of land transfer as judgment appears in Joshua 13:13 and Jeremiah 25:26. It reflects God's ultimate control over nations and territories (Psalm 22:28).

questions.question: What is the nature of God's judgment upon Edom according to Ezekiel 25?
options: Cutting off man and beast and making it desolate
Blessing it with peace and prosperity
Making Edom a refuge for Israel
Granting Edom a covenant of protection
questions.correctAnswer: Cutting off man and beast and making it desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:13 declares God will cut off man and beast from Edom and make it desolate. This comprehensive judgment reflects the gravity of Edom’s offense against Judah. Similar divine judgments on nations appear in Jeremiah 49:17-18 and Obadiah 1:10-14. The destruction of both man and beast indicates total desolation in God's just retribution (Nahum 1:3).

questions.question: What is the reason given for God's judgment against the Philistines in Ezekiel 25?
options: They acted with revenge and hatred to destroy Israel
They refused to worship the true God
questions.correctAnswer: They acted with revenge and hatred to destroy Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:15-16 explains God's judgment because the Philistines took vengeance with a spiteful heart to destroy Israel. This reveals God's hatred of malicious revenge and unjust violence (Proverbs 6:16-19). Similar judgments against enemies who act in hatred appear in Nahum 1:2-3 and Romans 12:19. God's justice demands accountability for such enmity.

questions.question: How will God execute His vengeance upon the Philistines as described in Ezekiel 25?
options: With furious rebukes and destruction of the remnant
By sending a prophet to warn them
By making them allies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: With furious rebukes and destruction of the remnant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:17 states God will execute great vengeance with furious rebukes, destroying the remaining Philistine population. This portrays God's righteous wrath against persistent enemies, consistent with Isaiah 13:11 and Revelation 6:16-17. The destruction of remnants underscores the completeness of His judgment.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 25, what phrase repeatedly emphasizes the purpose behind God's judgments on the nations?
options: So that they shall know that I am the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: So that they shall know that I am the LORD
questions.explanation: The refrain 'that they shall know that I am the LORD' appears in verses 5, 7, 11, 14, and 17. This highlights God's intent to reveal His sovereignty and holiness through judgment. Similar declarations occur in Exodus 9:16 and Isaiah 43:25. It confirms God's ultimate purpose is to make His name and character known (Psalm 46:10).

questions.question: Which group is specifically mentioned as instruments of judgment against Ammon and Moab in Ezekiel 25?
questions.correctAnswer: Men of the east
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:4 and 25:10 indicate God will deliver Ammon and Moab to the men of the east, using them as agents of judgment. This illustrates God’s providential use of foreign peoples (Habakkuk 1:6; Jeremiah 25:9). It reflects the principle that God can raise up nations for His purposes (Romans 9:17).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'clapped thine hands and stamped with the feet' in Ezekiel 25:6 symbolize regarding the Ammonites' attitude?
options: Joyful mockery and spite against Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Joyful mockery and spite against Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:6 uses this imagery to depict the Ammonites' malicious rejoicing over Israel's downfall. This symbolizes scorn and hostile delight, similar to Psalm 35:15 and Lamentations 2:15. It shows the human sin of rejoicing over others’ suffering, which God condemns (Proverbs 24:17).

questions.question: What theological theme about God's sovereignty is demonstrated by the judgments pronounced in Ezekiel 25?
options: God controls nations to execute justice and reveal His holiness
God is indifferent to nations' actions
God forgives all nations without judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God controls nations to execute justice and reveal His holiness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25 shows God sovereignly using nations as instruments of judgment and punishment. This theme is consistent with Isaiah 10:5-7, Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1, and Revelation 19:11, where God directs earthly powers to fulfill His righteous purposes and demonstrate His holiness.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 25 contribute to the doctrine of God's justice?
options: It illustrates God's righteous judgment against nations for their hostility and sins
It teaches that God ignores human sin
It shows God's favoritism towards the strongest nations
It denies any punishment for enemies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates God's righteous judgment against nations for their hostility and sins
questions.explanation: The chapter explicitly pronounces God's judgment on nations who opposed Israel, showing that God is just and punishes sin (Ezekiel 25:7, 11, 17). This corresponds to Romans 2:5-6, Psalm 9:7-8, and Nahum 1:3 which affirm God's justice on all peoples.

questions.question: What does the judgment against Edom in Ezekiel 25 reveal about God's response to vengeance and offense?
options: God punishes Edom for taking vengeance and greatly offending Judah
God blesses Edom for their peaceful ways
questions.correctAnswer: God punishes Edom for taking vengeance and greatly offending Judah
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25:12-13 explains God's judgment because Edom took vengeance and greatly offended Judah. This shows God opposes revenge and offenses against His people. Similar warnings appear in Proverbs 20:22 and Romans 12:19. God's justice demands accountability for hostile acts.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly demonstrated by the judgments pronounced in Ezekiel 25?
options: God's holiness and wrath against sin
God's partiality to all nations equally
questions.correctAnswer: God's holiness and wrath against sin
questions.explanation: The judgments in Ezekiel 25 reveal God's holy intolerance of sin and His righteous wrath (Ezekiel 25:5, 7, 17). This aligns with Leviticus 19:2, Romans 1:18, and Hebrews 12:29 emphasizing God's holiness and just anger toward sin.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 25 fit into the grand narrative of Scripture regarding God's covenant people?
options: It shows God's defense and vindication of His covenant people through judgment on their enemies
It teaches that God's people should become like their enemies
It emphasizes human strength over divine intervention
It suggests God will abandon His people
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's defense and vindication of His covenant people through judgment on their enemies
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 25 demonstrates God defending Israel and Judah by judging hostile nations. This theme appears in Exodus 15:3, Psalm 18:47, and Romans 8:31 where God acts to protect and vindicate His covenant people.
